node.title: Colorado’s governor says he is ‘frustrated’ with federal regulators about booster eligibility.
node.alt: Gov. Jared Polis of Colorado said this week that all adults in the state would be eligible for a booster shot of the coronavirus vaccine, assuming that enough time had passed since their initial doses.
node.description: Federal regulators are considering a request to make all adults eligible for Pfizer-BioNTech’s Covid boosters. Colorado and two other states decided to broaden access anyway.
node.content: ["As federal regulators consider a request to expand eligibility of Pfizer-BioNTech\u2019s coronavirus vaccine boosters to all adults, three states decided this past week to broaden access on their own.", "Colorado, New Mexico and California are allowing adults to seek out boosters, provided individuals are at least six months past the second dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccines, or two months past the single-dose Johnson & Johnson vaccine.", "\u201cI\u2019ve been very frustrated with the convoluted messaging out of the C.D.C. and the F.D.A.,\u201d said Gov. Jared Polis of Colorado on Sunday on the CBS show \u201cFace the Nation,\u201d referring to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention as well as the Food and Drug Administration.", "Federal regulators have said that adults who received the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccines are eligible for a booster if they are 65 or older, or if they are at increased risk because of medical conditions or where they work or live. People who got the Johnson & Johnson shot, which is available only to adults, are eligible. Those getting boosters can select any of the three vaccine brands.", "On Tuesday, Pfizer and BioNTech asked the F.D.A. to expand eligibility for their boosters to all adults. If the regulators sign off on that request, it would make official what health authorities say they already see happening frequently \u2014 that many people appear to be getting boosters whether or not they are technically eligible. In mid-August, President Biden announced plans to make boosters available to all adults, but the beginning of the campaign was delayed after regulators insisted they needed more time to review data.", "Mr. Polis signed an executive order this week on boosters, citing the significant spread of the virus across Colorado. As of Saturday, the state\u2019s daily average of hospitalizations had increased 13 percent over the past two weeks to about 1,500, according to a New York Times database.", "As winter bears down, Mr. Polis said he wanted to safeguard residents as well as ski tourists.", "\u201cEverybody should get the booster after six months,\u201d he said, emphasizing its ability to help with personal protection. \u201cThat\u2019s why my parents got it,\u201d he added, as did he.", "A growing body of early global research has shown that the vaccines available in the United States have remained highly protective against the disease\u2019s worst outcomes over time.", "A number of published studies show that their protection against infection, with or without symptoms, has fallen. Public health experts say it does not mean the vaccines are not working. But the significance of waning effectiveness \u2014 and whether it suggests that all adults should be eligible for a booster \u2014 is still up for debate.", "Dr. Scott Gottlieb, a former head of the F.D.A. who now sits on Pfizer\u2019s board, was blunt on \u201cFace the Nation\u201d in his criticism of the Biden administration\u2019s approach to booster recommendations. \u201cI think the confusing message around the boosters may end up being one of the biggest missed opportunities in this pandemic,\u201d he said.", "\u201cAnyone who\u2019s eligible for a booster, and most Americans probably are eligible at this point, should be going out and seeking it,\u201d he added.", "And on \u201cFox News Sunday,\u201d Dr. Vivek Murthy, the U.S. surgeon general, tried to walk a line between acknowledging the moves of those three states and defending the slower approaches by federal regulators.", "\u201cWhat they\u2019re going to do is take a close look at the data,\u201d he said of the F.D.A., to assure that the booster is safe and effective for people currently not eligible for it.", "He continued: \u201cThe bottom line is that millions of people can get boosted right now and we want them to get boosted, because that will both extend and enhance the protection that they\u2019ve already been getting from the vaccine.\u201d"]
